title: On his death bed Alexander is rumoured to have left his empire to 'the strongest' or 'toi kratistos'. How would this have been written in Greek of the period and what were the implications of these last words on the ancient world? - Quora

response.answer_text: On his death bed Alexander is rumoured to have left his empire to "the strongest" or "toi kratistos". How would this have been written in Greek of the period? as following τῷ κρατίστῳ - To the strongest/best  and what were the implications of these last words on the ancient world? To begin with, according to general Craterus, Alexander said “to Kratero” instead of “to kratisto”, thus claimed that Alexander chose him as his successor (“To Craterus”), his claim was however dismissed. The majority of the diadochoi saw it as a challenge before the eyes of the Gods to prove that they are the best, that they are capable and worthy to determine the fate of Alexander’s vast empire. Some saw it as a mockery or foreshadowing of their future squabblings and wars that would destroy Alexander’s own creation. Others understood it as Alexander’s revenge to his generals, who halted his advance in India, made him return back and perhaps poisoned him to get their share of glory, power and wealth. Finally, some interpreted it an act of arrogance by Alexander, that no one were to succeed him, build upon his legacy, live similar glory and achievements, as that phrase or should i say command would certainly lead the successors to war, division and utter destruction.  Perseus, the last king of Macedonia, paraded through the streets of Rome defeated  Cleopatra VII, the last Queen of Ptolemaic Egypt and the last of the successors, commiting suicide

It’s possible that he actually said Krateros, one of his generals. Unfortunately for Krateros, he wasn’t there to witness Alexander’s death. So the rest may have claimed that he said, To kratisto (Τω κρατίστω), or “the strongest”. The implication is that an empire was divided, and doomed to eventually fail.
